modelCorrections.rawOutput: Here's the corrected HTML based on the WCAG 2.1 violation description and the provided examples: - Incorrect HTML: - Corrected HTML: Explanation: The original HTML had an empty anchor tag with no accessible text. To fix this, I added the `aria-label` attribute to the anchor tag, providing a descriptive label for screen readers. The `aria-label` attribute is used to specify the accessible name for an element when there is no visible text content. By adding `aria-label="Taylor Corporation Instagram"`, screen readers will announce the purpose of the link as "Taylor Corporation Instagram" when the user focuses on or interacts with the anchor tag.

Here's the corrected HTML based on the WCAG 2.1 violation description: - Corrected HTML: Explanation: To fix the accessibility issue, I added the `aria-label` attribute with the value "Facebook" to provide accessible text for the link. The `aria-label` attribute is used to define a string that labels the current element for assistive technologies. By adding `aria-label="Facebook"`, screen readers will announce the link as "Facebook" instead of just announcing it as a link without any context. This helps users understand the purpose of the link and where it leads to. The `aria-hidden="true"` attribute on the `` element is correct and should be kept as is. It ensures that the icon itself is not announced by screen readers, as the `aria-label` on the parent `` element provides the necessary information.
